title: New logging platform
description:
## Original Description

CloudWatch is not a sufficient logging platform:

* Search is too slow
* Too hard to find things

# Updates

## Joshua's Requirements for Our New Logging Platform

* Able to use CloudWatch as a source of truth (i.e. pull logs from CloudWatch)
* Performant over any query (I may want to search over logs from the past year)
* JSON structured metadata (preferred)
* Ability to bucket over metadata (i.e. search logs for rest-api or logs for worker)
* Able to do keyword searches combined with time and bucket parameters (i.e. search matching "timeout" over rest-api logs over past week)

title: Refactor workspace using Nx
description:
## About Nx

Nx is a monorepo management tool that provides tremendous value to any repo (monorepo or not).

It contains a ton of code generation and project config tools (Vite, Typescript, pacakges, etc).

A key Nx feature is the ability to run a task only on packages that have current changes (as opposed to running a task on the entire workspace): [https://nx.dev/features/run-tasks#run-tasks-on-projects-affected-by-a-pr](https://nx.dev/features/run-tasks#run-tasks-on-projects-affected-by-a-pr)

Read about Nx here: [https://nx.dev/](https://nx.dev/)

## Scope

The scope of this task will deal with converting the workspace into an Nx workspace. The refactor will largely be around project config, tooling, and directory structure.

Although some changes to the code itself will be required, effort should be made to keep these changes to a minimum (including the directory structure of the code).

## Effort

This is not a small task. A large amount of effort will need to be put into making sure that all of our existing tooling (i.e. all of our npm scripts) either still work or are properly replaced at the end of the refactor. This will require collaboration by multiple engineers.

## Gains

Refactoring to Nx gives us the opportunity to speed up our CI/CD by only building images where the code has been changed (i.e. don't rebuild the backend for frontend only PRs). HOWEVER, this gain may require extra effort depending on how the build and deployment in CI/CD is currently set up.

Nx also lessens the load introduced by implementing required PR checks in [ENG-6097](https://linear.app/buildbetter/issue/ENG-6097/run-type-checking-in-ci) [ENG-6099](https://linear.app/buildbetter/issue/ENG-6099/run-linting-in-ci) and [ENG-6100](https://linear.app/buildbetter/issue/ENG-6100/run-testing-in-ci).

Lastly, refactoring to Nx will either complete or accelerate the completion of the following issues:

* [ENG-6093](https://linear.app/buildbetter/issue/ENG-6093/increase-strictness-of-typescript)
* [ENG-6096](https://linear.app/buildbetter/issue/ENG-6096/enable-type-checking-in-web-app)
* [ENG-6097](https://linear.app/buildbetter/issue/ENG-6097/run-type-checking-in-ci)
* [ENG-6098](https://linear.app/buildbetter/issue/ENG-6098/configure-typescript-to-use-source-not-build-of-dependent-packages)
* [ENG-6099](https://linear.app/buildbetter/issue/ENG-6099/run-linting-in-ci)
* [ENG-6100](https://linear.app/buildbetter/issue/ENG-6100/run-testing-in-ci)

title: Run testing in CI
description:
Currently we're not running tests at all, which discourages the writing of new tests, as a result, most of our codebase has no tests.

Run tests in CI both as a required PR step and as a part of our build.

Note: @nikhil spoke about a bug in our current testing setup which results in tests taking minutes to spool up before they even start running. This configuration issue will likely need to be solved as a part of this issue.

Note: Other CI issues that introduce required PR steps can probably be implemented by running the check for the entire codebase. For testing, a solution will likely need to be implemented (if not already) that only runs tests on affected code.

title: Run linting in CI
description:
Currently, linting is only run automatically as a part of a commit hook, which is dependent on the local env and can be bypassed.

Run linting in CI both as a part of our build and as a required PR step to ensure that there are no lint errors in our codebase before deploying.

title: Configure typescript to use source (not build) of dependent packages
description:
If the `rest-api` package depends on the `common` package, then any type changes in `common` are not picked up by the typescript process for `rest-api` until compile has been ran in `common`.

Instead, the typescript process for `rest-api` should immediately see any changes to the source in `common` without having to build `common` first.

Doing this will enable our IDEs to pick up changes to dependent packages in whatever package is currently being developed.

title: Run type checking in CI
description:
Currently, no automatic type checking is done at any point, so type errors can be pushed and merged into `main`.

Automatic type checking should first be implemented both in CI steps required to pass before a PR can be merged and CI steps as a part of our build. Additional places, like fixing it in lint-staged may also be done.

Recommend doing after [ENG-6096](https://linear.app/buildbetter/issue/ENG-6096/enable-type-checking-in-web-app).

title: Enable type checking in `web-app`
description:
* Uncomment vite checker config

Fix type errors in the `web-app` package

title: Creating a new chat keeps the last chats last question in the text field despite it already being sent

title: Increase strictness of typescript
description:
We should be stricter in our typescript code, doing so accelerates development:

* Update `tsconfig.base.json` target to something newer, probably `es2022`
* Remove dom, dom.Iterable, and request libs from common package
* Remove disabled compile options from:
  * common
  * worker


* Enable `no-explicity-any` lint rule
* Require `override` keyword: `"noImplicitOverride": true`
* Enable exhaustive switch statements: [https://typescript-eslint.io/rules/switch-exhaustiveness-check/](https://typescript-eslint.io/rules/switch-exhaustiveness-check/)

Implement the above configurations and update the codebase.

Recommend doing after [ENG-6096](https://linear.app/buildbetter/issue/ENG-6096/enable-type-checking-in-web-app).

title: Clean up #internal-monitoring and #fail-whale
description:
```
Currently there is a lot of noise in #internal-monitoring. Every message should be a
priority item for engineering to solve (if this is not the intended use case of this
channel, then another channel should be setup with this use case). Cleaning up this
channel consists of:
- Resolving legitimate issues
- Lowering severity of non-legitimate issues
- Increasing thresholds of non-legitimate alerts
```

title: Allow concurrent processing of jobs
description:
```
Presumably, the decision to have each worker only process one job at a time was taken for
a good reason. Assuming we don't want to change this, then we should implement auto scaling
of our workers. One long job (for any reason) should not prevent the execution of every
other job in our app. Presumably, there is already logic in place that prevents multiple
workers from taking the same job.
```

If we don't have a reason for sequentially processing jobs inside a single work, then implementing concurrent processing may be sufficient for now. Eventually, we'll need auto scaling.

If we go the autoscaling route, in addition to confirming that the visibility logic prevents workers from taking the same job, we should also confirm that it doesn't allow workers to hog every message they receive.

title: Refactor Rate Limiter Logic
description:
```markdown
The first and most obvious step should be to refactor our rate limiters to not simply
pause the job but rather to end the job and store some state in the database telling
the worker that the job was paused and not to resume it for the allotted time. This
could be done at either the job level or the external API level. This will allow
workers to continue to process other jobs until the API limit is reset.
```

A better implementation might be to actually send delayed SQS message, but we would want to implement better visibility for this somehow so that we can see a job is delayed.

title: Add company to People
description:
Users want the ability to associate a person with a Company in Buildbetter.

**Why**

Users want the ability to filter data throughout the app based on company.  For example: *Show me all signals from customers at Google.*

**What needs to happen**

* Setup/adjust current data models to fit the storage needs for this feature.  (I believe this data model already exists but I would check with @nikhil)
* Setup components, queries, mutations to add, remove Company from the customer profile.  This should also be the place where the user can create a new company by typing in the company name (if the name is not found, offer create option - create the company using the typed in value as name).
* Setup a new component/view so the user can click on a company from the People profile and add, edit, remove the details of that company.

**Nice to have**

* Allow the user to add people to a company via the company page.
* Add custom properties to the company. (Same format as [ENG-5719](https://linear.app/buildbetter/issue/ENG-5719/add-custom-properties-to-people))

**Figma Doc**

[People / Customer View / Add Company - Desktop App (Figma)](https://www.figma.com/design/bqH0Xnz1g5IiVxAMOpJpnW/Desktop-App?node-id=148-251780&t=cjn9hMVivj6qXjgX-4)

[People / Company View - Desktop App (Figma)](https://www.figma.com/design/bqH0Xnz1g5IiVxAMOpJpnW/Desktop-App?node-id=155-99065&t=cjn9hMVivj6qXjgX-4)

title: Add custom properties to People
description:
Users want to have the ability to add, edit, and delete custom meta data on people inside of BuildBetter.  In the future this meta data will most likely come into BuildBetter via a sync with CRM tools like Hubspot and Salesforce.

**Why**

Users want to use this meta data to filter data throughout the app.  For example: *Show me all signals from customers where inbound was Google Ads.*

**What needs to happen**

* Setup/adjust current data models to fit the storage needs for this feature.  (I would check with @nikhil because there was talk about merging our existing CRM custom properties with a new data model around meta data)
* Reformat the customer page to be a three panel setup so we have proper space to add custom properties.
* Setup components, queries, mutations to add, edit, remove meta data from the customer profile.

**Nice to have**

* For now all properties will just be string key/value pairs.  A nice little frontend touch would be to auto link properties that we know.  So if a link is added, make the link look nice and clickable (see Figma).
* Allow the user to pick from a set of icons they wish to use for the property.  Or we could even just let them use emojis?
* Auto complete property names so the user doesn't end up creating multiple property names for the same data (email, email address) etc.

**Figma Doc**

[People / Customer View - Desktop App (Figma)](https://www.figma.com/design/bqH0Xnz1g5IiVxAMOpJpnW/Desktop-App?node-id=148-115778&t=cjn9hMVivj6qXjgX-4)
